bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 6, 1876

div1.p: Reed describes the visit of dignitaries - including General William T. Sherman - to the post at Willet's Point.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 6, 1876
div1.p:
In con-
cluding my last letter, I was
forced to do so somewhat
abrumptly, as the sound
of the drum told me that the
Steamer, with its disting-
uished guests, was ap-
proaching. Buckling on
my sword, with all celer-
ity, I rushed down to the
wharf, in company with
General Abbott & his other
Staff officers. A moment
after the Battallion, coming
at a double quick, had reached
the wharf & was drawn up
with in double file- By this
time, the steamer, handsomely
decorated with flags, had
approached the dock & soon
she was made fast- As
the Secretary of War & Genl
Sherman stepped off the boat,
the cannon which had been
charged, broke forth in
one tremendous volley, &
immediately the Band began
to pour forth “Hail to the
Chief-” Being one of the Staff
Officers, I was, at once, in
troduced to the Secretary &
Gen. Sherman & had the pleasure
of grasping their hands- Besides
these, there were many distin-
guished military officers in
Company with the Secretary,
Major General Hancock, among
the rest- We soon march by
past the Battallion, which
had come to “present arms,
& in the midst of descending
floods, we marched to the Tor-
pedo Building. General
Sherman excused the Battl
from the Review, which
was to have taken place, on
account of the pouring
rain which came down
in torrents- So it was,
we all got thoroughly wet,
for we had to escort the par-
ty around through the Fort.
After this, the Secretary wit-
nessed the explosion of a tor-
pedo out in the Sound &
then, embarking on Board
the Steamer, took course for
New York- I was very much
pleased with General Sher-
man, chiefly because he seem-
ed so modest & unassuming,
for one occupying so high
a position- General Hancock
complimented me by telling
me that I looked like a soldier,
but added that I was a
very young looking doctor!
And now a word on one
or two matters mentioned in
your last letter. Really, it strikes
me, my darling Emilie, that you
are very liberal to be giving
me away so readily to another
young lady, especially one whom
I have never seen, & hence
don't know whether I should
be pleased with her- Perhaps
this was the reason of your
great generosity, wasn't it?
Now had it been “Miss Vie,”
instead of Miss Mollie, I could
have only have politely bowed
my thanks & acquiescence.
It would sound so pretty
to say, “oh! my, sweet little
Vie”! The poetic effect, you observe.
I have yet another objec-
tion to your liberality. It
is that I am not yet tired
of belonging to my precious
little Emilie, & I don't want
to be given away to any-
body else in this world!
And I won't be given away
neither! And if old Mr July
or August, or whatever his name
is, don't stop sending sen-
ding messages to my
little sweet-heart, I'll make
it a good deal warmer for
him than his name would
imply! You can tell him
so, too! In reply to the
the remark that I had neglected to invite
you to the Theatrical Performance, I as-
sure you, darling, that I was going to send
you an invitation before the performance
came off. I find, however, that I will not
take part, owing to the fact that I will not remain
here long enough to contribute my services-
Dr Heger received a letter from the Surgeon Genl
on Monday, stating that I would soon be relieved
from duty, at this post, & I am, daily, expecting my
orders to arrive- Don't stop your letters, as I will not leave
for a week after my orders arrive.
